#Text=Choose a Dental Implant Surgeon
#Text=Getting dental implants requires precision reconstructive surgery .
#Text=You do n’t just want anyone operating on your mouth ; you want an expert .
#Text=So , how do you find the right dentist for the job ?
#Text=The best surgeons will have the perfect combination of credentials , facilities and reputation .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Check for AAID Certification .
#Text=The simplest way to narrow your list of dentists is to use AAID ( American Academy of Implant Dentistry ) certification as your first requirement .
#Text=There are several types of dentists who might have this certification , including general dentists , periodon'tists , prosthodon'tists and oral surgeons .
#Text=Any dentist who performs surgical and/or restorative procedures could potentially acquire certification .

#Text=And , if they hold that certificate , you know that they are competent in all phases of implant dentistry , have at least five years of experience , are actively involved in leadership roles and have completed at least 400 hours of continuing education .
#Text=It ’s a great place to start !
#Text=Inquire About In-Office Technology .
#Text=Advancements in dental technology have given implant dentists incredible tools to work with ; but , not all offices are state-of-the-art .
#Text=The Cone Beam CT , for example , is a 3D imaging device that can provide views of soft tissue , bone , muscle , and blood vessels , without sacrificing clarity .
#Text=This allows dentists to plan treatment properly , and safely place implants with incredible precision .
#Text=Choosing a dentist with in-office access to this technology and others minimizes your risk , while maximizing your convenience .
#Text=Find Out If They Have an In-House Surgical Suite .
#Text=Some dental procedures require multiple visits to the office .
#Text=The actual surgery may even take place off-site at a hospital or other surgical facility .
#Text=These are things to consider carefully .
#Text=Ask your candidate dentists not only what the “ turn-around time ” is , but how many visits to expect and where you might have to go .
#Text=Some will have a surgical suite in-house , which tends to make the process quicker and more convenient overall .
#Text=If your surgery will be performed with IV sedation , you will want to find out if your doctor is certified to perform IV sedation , or if other doctors will be involved .
#Text=Research Their Reputation .
#Text=Just because you “ know ” your current dentist , does n’t mean he or she is right for your reconstructive surgery .
#Text=There is no harm in asking about their credentials or experience in dental implants , after all , you did n’t need to know until now .
#Text=Ask about their success rate .
#Text=Ask to see before and after photos .
#Text=If they do n’t do implants , ask for a referral .
#Text=Implant dentistry is a very competitive specialty , and most dentists expect these types of inquiries .
#Text=Use the Internet to dig up some reviews from other dental implant patients .
#Text=Just be careful to look at the big picture , as a single review ( good or bad ) may not paint the most accurate picture .
#Text=And , of course , ask around .
#Text=More people in your circle of acquaintances may have dental implant experience than you think !
#Text=Tips
#Text=At the end of the day , choosing any doctor will go beyond a checklist of “ must haves ” and “ nice to haves ” .
#Text=Talk to the staff and meet the surgeon .
#Text=Being comfortable with the dentist is important , too .
